slides.text_joined: December | 2025 | Family Dinneroo | Dish Analysis
Summary

text_runs: Current coverage of high-priority dishes is materially constrained - particularly across Indian, British, Mexican, and Middle Eastern cuisines
Coverage Gap by Dish (% of active zones where the dish is not available)
There are significant gaps (50%+) in coverage
These are concentrated in specific cuisines.
Notably the largest high-priority gaps are in
(protein & veg, shepherd’s pie, grain bowl), then
(fajitas, quesadillas) and Middle Eastern (shawarma). Asian has only small gaps and Italian is effectively fully covered.
This is primarily a px-base problem rather than a menu-mix problem.

In general, the issue is not that px are offering the wrong dishes; it is that we simply lack enough scaled Indian, British, Mexican and Middle Eastern px, and / or enough scaled multi-cuisine px capable of offering these dishes at meaningful coverage.
slides.text_joined: Current coverage of high-priority dishes is materially constrained - particularly across Indian, British, Mexican, and Middle Eastern cuisines | Decreasing Priority | Coverage Gap by Dish (% of active zones where the dish is not available) | As at 12-Dec | Core Drivers | Demand Boosters | Preference Drivers | There are significant gaps (50%+) in coverage | of key priority dishes. | These are concentrated in specific cuisines. | Notably the largest high-priority gaps are in | Indian | (curry, biryani), followed by | British | (protein & veg, shepherd’s pie, grain bowl), then | Mexican | (fajitas, quesadillas) and Middle Eastern (shawarma). Asian has only small gaps and Italian is effectively fully covered. | This is primarily a px-base problem rather than a menu-mix problem. | In general, the issue is not that px are offering the wrong dishes; it is that we simply lack enough scaled Indian, British, Mexican and Middle Eastern px, and / or enough scaled multi-cuisine px capable of offering these dishes at meaningful coverage. | Commentary | Indian | Asian | Italian | British | Mexican | Middle Eastern

text_runs: There are 3 key levers to address these gaps, 2 of which can be delivered through existing px and 1 of which requires new px onboarding
Introduce underserved cuisines via multi-cuisine px
Work with px to strengthen their menus within their core cuisine (e.g. encouraging Asian px to expand into noodles, sushi)
Work with px to improve the quality and structure of their dishes, including (i) upgrading ingredients
Onboard new px in a highly targeted way to fill priority dish gaps that cannot be addressed through the existing px base
Work with multi-cuisine px to add dishes in underserved cuisines, (e.g. working with Bill’s to help close gaps in Indian coverage)
slides.text_joined: There are 3 key levers to address these gaps, 2 of which can be delivered through existing px and 1 of which requires new px onboarding | Optimise depth within existing cuisines | Optimise dish quality and structure | Introduce underserved cuisines via multi-cuisine px | Onboard new px | Work with px to strengthen their menus within their core cuisine (e.g. encouraging Asian px to expand into noodles, sushi) | Work with px to improve the quality and structure of their dishes, including (i) upgrading ingredients | (ii) improving customisation options | (iii) introducing mix & match bundles | Onboard new px in a highly targeted way to fill priority dish gaps that cannot be addressed through the existing px base | Work with multi-cuisine px to add dishes in underserved cuisines, (e.g. working with Bill’s to help close gaps in Indian coverage) | Optimising with existing px | Out of scope | (addressed via the px-level reporting workstream) | Adding new px | Levers to Address Dish Gaps | As at 12-Dec

text_runs: We believe closing gaps will be primarily driven by new px onboarding, with existing px actions offering more marginal uplift
Priority Actions to Address Dish Gaps
Work with Bill's to introduce a curry
Work with relevant Asian px to introduce Noodles (Wagamama, Banana Tree)
Work with relevant Mexican px to introduce Fajitas (Zambrero)
Work with relevant Asian px to introduce Rice Bowls (Iro, Asia Villa)
Work with relevant Asian px to introduce Sushi (Iro, Kokoro, Asia Villa) and test & learn this
Onboard new Indian px; largest ones: Holy Cow (25% coverage of active zones), Dhaba@49 (17%), Rajah Rowing (15%)
Onboard new British / multi-cuisine px; largest ones: Nando's (99%), The Jerk Valley (21%), Mildreds (21%), Assenheims 56 (16%), Toby Carvery (11%)
Onboard new Mexican px; largest ones: Chipotle (31%), Wahaca (31%), Brorittos (19%), BarBurrito (19%), Boojum (11%)
Onboard Middle Eastern px; largest ones: The Athenian (44%), Comptoir (20%), Pita (11%), Kervan Sofrasi (10%)
Onboard new 'Healthy' px; largest ones: main grain (28%), Pure (16%), Urban Greens (15%)

Deep-Dive

text_runs: We define Family Dinneroo MVP at zone level as 5+ px, 4+ cuisines and 10+ dishes.
At this threshold, we observe comparatively low variety complaints, high cx satisfaction and high repeat.
However, variety is not just about volume - the mix of dishes matters.
Using internal performance data and survey insights, we have prioritised dishes into 3 priority groups and additionally defined a dish-level MVP for each.
Noodles 🇯🇵,  Indian curry 🇮🇳. These combine high demand with strong cx preference. They are established takeaway favourites that also work well as family meals.

Katsu 🇯🇵, Sushi 🇯🇵, Pho 🇯🇵,  Biryani 🇮🇳, Pizza 🇮🇹, Pasta 🇮🇹, Lasagne 🇮🇹, Protein & Veg 🇬🇧. These see strong demand but weaker preference. They tend to be traditional takeaway staples that are less embedded in family dining.

Shepherd’s Pie 🇬🇧, Grain Bowl 🇬🇧, Fajitas 🇲🇽, Quesadillas 🇲🇽, Shawarma 🇱🇧, Rice Bowl 🇯🇵, Fried Rice 🇯🇵, East Asian Curry 🇯🇵. These are loved by cx who try them but are not yet widely discovered. They skew towards family-style meals that are less associated with traditional takeaway behaviour.
Our current coverage does not reflect this prioritisation.
It is heavily skewed towards Asian and Italian, with materially lower coverage across Indian, British, Mexican and Middle Eastern cuisines.

This is primarily a px-base problem rather than a menu-mix problem. In general, the issue is not that px are offering the wrong dishes; it is that we simply lack enough scaled Indian, British, Mexican and Middle Eastern px, and / or enough scaled multi-cuisine px capable of offering these dishes at meaningful coverage

These combine high demand with strong cx preference. They are established takeaway favourites that also work well as family meals. | Demand Boosters (MVP = 75% coverage): | Katsu 🇯🇵, Sushi 🇯🇵, Pho 🇯🇵,  Biryani 🇮🇳, Pizza 🇮🇹, Pasta 🇮🇹, Lasagne 🇮🇹, Protein & Veg 🇬🇧. These see strong demand but weaker preference. They tend to be traditional takeaway staples that are less embedded in family dining. | Preference Drivers (MVP = 50% coverage): | Shepherd’s Pie 🇬🇧, Grain Bowl 🇬🇧, Fajitas 🇲🇽, Quesadillas 🇲🇽, Shawarma 🇱🇧, Rice Bowl 🇯🇵, Fried Rice 🇯🇵, East Asian Curry 🇯🇵. These are loved by cx who try them but are not yet widely discovered. They skew towards family-style meals that are less associated with traditional takeaway behaviour. | Our current coverage does not reflect this prioritisation. | It is heavily skewed towards Asian and Italian, with materially lower coverage across Indian, British, Mexican and Middle Eastern cuisines. | This is primarily a px-base problem rather than a menu-mix problem. In general, the issue is not that px are offering the wrong dishes; it is that we simply lack enough scaled Indian, British, Mexican and Middle Eastern px, and / or enough scaled multi-cuisine px capable of offering these dishes at meaningful coverage | (with Bill’s currently the only example).

text_runs: This is visible at dish level.
Most Asian and Italian dishes are well covered, whereas there is not a single Indian, British, Mexican or Middle Eastern dish with strong coverage today.
The largest high-priority gaps are in Indian (curry, biryani), followed by British (protein & veg, shepherd’s pie, grain bowl), then Mexican (fajitas, quesadillas) and Middle Eastern (shawarma).
Asian has only small gaps and Italian is effectively fully covered.
There are three levers to close these gaps, 2 through existing px and 1 through new px onboarding:
Existing px: optimise depth within existing cuisines by working with px to strengthen their core menus
(e.g. where relevant, encouraging Asian px to expand into noodles).
Existing px: introduce underserved cuisines via multi-cuisine px
(e.g. working with Bill’s to address Indian coverage gaps).
in a targeted way to fill priority dish gaps that cannot be addressed through the current px
Given that the largest gaps stem from a lack of relevant cuisine px, the impact achievable through existing px is constrained.

While there are some incremental improvements - notably working with relevant Asian px to introduce more noodles, rice bowls, sushi and fried rice, with Mexican px to add fajitas, and with Bill’s to introduce a curry - these will not be sufficient to close the core gaps.
Meaningful progress on variety will therefore require targeted onboarding of scaled px,
with highest priority on Indian, followed by British and Mexican, then Middle Eastern and healthy. We have shortlisted the px that would deliver the greatest step-change in coverage.

We have shortlisted the px that would deliver the greatest step-change in coverage. | Note: breaking out Asian further

text_runs: We propose a zone MVP of 5+ px, 4+ cuisines, 10+ dishes
1. Dish = Unique meal item in Dinneroo bundle. Main not side.

text_runs: The specific dishes available also matter; thus, we have also grouped dishes by priority and assigned an MVP coverage by dish group
High cx demand and strong preference
Tend to be dishes that are both established takeaway favourites and family favourite meals
High cx demand but weaker preference
(cx order them often, but don’t love them yet)
Tend to be dishes that are established takeaway favourites but not uniquely associated with family dining
Katsu 🇯🇵, Sushi 🇯🇵, Pho 🇯🇵,  Biryani 🇮🇳, Pizza 🇮🇹, Pasta 🇮🇹, Lasagne 🇮🇹, Protein & Veg 🇬🇧.
ensure strong availability and work with px to improve quality
Strong preference but lower cx demand
(loved by those who try them, but not widely discovered)
Tend to be family favourite meals that are less embedded in traditional takeaway behaviour
Shepherd’s Pie 🇬🇧, Grain Bowl 🇬🇧, Rice Bowl 🇯🇵, Fried Rice 🇯🇵, East Asian Curry 🇯🇵, Fajitas 🇲🇽, Quesadillas 🇲🇽, Shawarma 🇱🇧
ensure solid availability and use discovery levers to grow demand as cx behaviour shifts towards less traditional takeaway
Not available on Family Dinneroo today, but requested
by cx and rated highly for family suitability
Pastry Pie 🇬🇧, Fish & Chips 🇬🇧, Roast 🇬🇧, Casserole 🇬🇧, Mezze 🇱🇧
pilot and iterate - build learning loops before scaling
revisit only if cx behaviour materially changes

text_runs: We have prioritised dishes using a combination of demand signals and customer preference indicators
Total orders for the dish divided by the number of times it is listed
% of Relevant Zones Where Dish Ranks Top #3
Percentage of zones in which the dish is a top 3 selling item, considering only zones where the dish is available
Indicates demand for dish, normalised for both availability and zone-level demand differences (e.g. higher baseline volumes in C
Volume of cx mentions requesting this dish be added to the menu
Captures explicit unmet demand for dish
Average rating for the dish on Family Dinneroo  orders
satisfaction with experience (including - but not limited to - dish)
Percentage of cx who report being “satisfied” or “very satisfied” with the dish
Percentage of customers who are “likely” or “very likely” to order the same dish again
based on frequency of consumption, difficulty of home preparation, and desire to see the dish available in-app
Provides insight into consumer appeal of dish

text_runs: % of Relevant Zones Where Dish Ranks Top #3
Open-Text Requests for Dish (% of requesters)

1. Demand strength is calculated by indexing each metric to an average of 1 and then taking the mean of average sales per dish, % zones rank top #3 and open-text requests. Cx preference is calculated in the same way using indexed Deliveroo rating, meal satisfaction score, and repeat-intent score. Where a metric is unavailable it is excluded from the average. For test & learn dishes, open-text request volume is used as the demand-strength proxy and dish-suitability rating is used as the customer-preference proxy.
Demand drivers perform particularly well on demand metrics; they are typically foods more closely associated with takeaway occasions.
Core drivers perform strongly across all indicators

text_runs: Our current coverage does not reflect this prioritisation - in aggregate, we offer c.157
dishes, with a strong skew towards Asian and Italian
1. Dish counts are based on the number of listed items. Where bundles offer a choice of 2+ distinct dish types (e.g. noodle dishes, rice bowls, or curries), each option is counted as a separate item.
2. Colours indicate the predominant cuisine. This mapping is not one-to-one; e.g. “Grain Bowls” appear under both “Healthy” and “Middle Eastern” cuisines.

text_runs: Zone Cuisine Coverage (% of Active Zones with ≥1 Dish per Cuisine)
available in almost all active zones
In contrast, coverage for all other cuisines is highly limited: in 50-75% of zones there is not a single dish available from these cuisines,
indicating that the primary constraint is a lack of scaled px rather than menu depth
Depth within cuisine is therefore a secondary issue and is most relevant for Middle Eastern and British;
for other cuisines, where they are present, depth is generally strong
At zone level, the issue is not that we are offering the wrong dishes, but that we lack sufficient, scale px in key cuisines

text_runs: Zone Dish Coverage (% of Active Zones with ≥1 Dish)
Asian and Italian dishes dominate on both breadth and depth of coverage
, with particularly strong representation across East Asian curries, katsu, rice bowls, noodles (Asian) and pasta and pizza (Italian)
driven by scale, multi-cuisine px (e.g. Bill’s) offering them
Mexican, Indian, and Healthy dishes show constrained breadth
due to the limited geographic footprint of px
This is evident at dish level: Asian and Italian cuisines are generally well covered, whereas all other cuisines show material gaps

text_runs: Combining our prioritisation and coverage analysis, the key priority gaps are concentrated in Indian, British, Mexican and Middle Eastern dishes
Coverage Gap by Dish (% of active zones where the dish is not available)
There are significant gaps (50%+) in coverage
These are concentrated in specific cuisines.
Notably the largest high-priority gaps are in
(protein & veg, shepherd’s pie, grain bowl), then
(fajitas, quesadillas) and Middle Eastern (shawarma). Asian has only small gaps and Italian is effectively fully covered.
This is primarily a px-base problem rather than a menu-mix problem.

In general, the issue is not that px are offering the wrong dishes; it is that we simply lack enough scaled Indian, British, Mexican and Middle Eastern px, and / or enough scaled multi-cuisine px capable of offering these dishes at meaningful coverage.
To Do: Add in % meeting threshold

Asian has only small gaps and Italian is effectively fully covered. | This is primarily a px-base problem rather than a menu-mix problem. | In general, the issue is not that px are offering the wrong dishes; it is that we simply lack enough scaled Indian, British, Mexican and Middle Eastern px, and / or enough scaled multi-cuisine px capable of offering these dishes at meaningful coverage. | Commentary | To Do: Add in % meeting threshold

text_runs: There are 3 key levers to address these gaps, 2 of which can be delivered through existing px and 1 of which requires new px onboarding
Introduce underserved cuisines via multi-cuisine px
Work with px to strengthen their menus within their core cuisine (e.g. encouraging Asian px to expand into noodles, sushi)
Work with px to improve the quality and structure of their dishes, including (i) upgrading ingredients
Onboard new px in a highly targeted way to fill priority dish gaps that cannot be addressed through the existing px base
Work with multi-cuisine px to add dishes in underserved cuisines, (e.g. working with Bill’s to help close gaps in Indian coverage)
slides.text_joined: There are 3 key levers to address these gaps, 2 of which can be delivered through existing px and 1 of which requires new px onboarding | Optimise depth within existing cuisines | Optimise dish quality and structure | Introduce underserved cuisines via multi-cuisine px | Onboard new px | Work with px to strengthen their menus within their core cuisine (e.g. encouraging Asian px to expand into noodles, sushi) | Work with px to improve the quality and structure of their dishes, including (i) upgrading ingredients | (ii) improving customisation options | (iii) introducing mix & match bundles | Onboard new px in a highly targeted way to fill priority dish gaps that cannot be addressed through the existing px base | Work with multi-cuisine px to add dishes in underserved cuisines, (e.g. working with Bill’s to help close gaps in Indian coverage) | Optimising with existing px | Out of scope | (addressed via the px-level reporting workstream) | Adding new px | Levers to Address Dish Gaps | As at 12-Dec

text_runs: The 2 existing px levers are relatively constrained - owing to limitedness in scale players and limited scale in multi-cuisine players gaps are

The largest dish gaps - Indian (curry, biryani), British (protein & veg, shepherd’s pie, grain bowl), Mexican (fajitas, quesadillas) and Middle Eastern (shawarma) - are driven by a structural shortage of relevant cuisine px. T
hese dishes cannot realistically be supplied by Asian or Italian px, leaving us dependent on a very small pool of scaled multi-cuisine partners (Bill’s and to a lesser extent Remedy
Smaller gaps can be addressed by optimising depth within existing cuisines
(e.g. encouraging Wagamama to add noodles), but these actions are more incremental.
Meaningful progress on dish variety will therefore require targeted onboarding of scaled px in the priority cuisines.

text_runs: We believe closing gaps will be primarily driven by new px onboarding, with existing px actions offering more marginal uplift
Priority Actions to Address Dish Gaps
Work with Bill's to introduce a curry
Work with relevant Asian px to introduce Noodles (Wagamama, Banana Tree)
Work with relevant Mexican px to introduce Fajitas (Zambrero)
Work with relevant Asian px to introduce Rice Bowls (Iro, Asia Villa)
Work with relevant Asian px to introduce Sushi (Iro, Kokoro, Asia Villa) and test & learn this
Onboard new Indian px; largest ones: Holy Cow (25% coverage of active zones), Dhaba@49 (17%), Rajah Rowing (15%)
Onboard new British / multi-cuisine px; largest ones: Nando's (99%), The Jerk Valley (21%), Mildreds (21%), Assenheims 56 (16%), Toby Carvery (11%)
Onboard new Mexican px; largest ones: Chipotle (31%), Wahaca (31%), Brorittos (19%), BarBurrito (19%), Boojum (11%)
Onboard Middle Eastern px; largest ones: The Athenian (44%), Comptoir (20%), Pita (11%), Kervan Sofrasi (10%)
Onboard new 'Healthy' px; largest ones;  largest ones: main grain (28%), Pure (16%), Urban Greens (15%)
